text: hello and welcome to AWS purpose-built
database strategy the right tool for the
right job as part of the AWS innovate
online conference my name is Blair
Leighton and I'm the business
development manager for database
services in asia-pacific I'll be taking
you through how the database market is
changing why you should be considering
using the right database for the right
job and providing an overview of some
AWS database services the database
market is changing considerably from the
1970s to the 2000s relational databases
reign supreme however in the 2000s as
the internet grew people started to hit
problems with relational databases this
resulted in Amazon developing the dynamo
technology and an associated paper that
was published in 2007 that led to the
development of DynamoDB in 2012 we have
seen a number of other new databases
released around this time such as
MongoDB Riak
Cassandra and CouchDB this means that
there is far more choices in the
database market today than there has
ever been before now let's take a look
at a traditional application and
database architecture still in use today
especially in the enterprise market you
have a client tier accessing an
application or web tier then the
accesses to the relational database that
database is used for all workloads and
all types of data whether it is simple
key value access complex queries or even
heavy query analytics that require full
tablespoons the one relational database
is expected to perform all these tasks
effectively over the years as new types
of workloads and data have evolved the
relational database has evolved with
these demands to be the Swiss Army knife
of database but is it trying to do too
much when deploying applications in the
cloud we believe that you should choose
the best database or datastore for the
workload rather than try to expect one
monolithic database to do it all if you
have a lot of read requests on a set of
data then it is more suited to be placed
in a cache simple key value data
like checking the status of a package
delivery can be pushed into a no sequel
database analytics can be moved to a
dedicated data warehouse logging in the
database is something that we see quite
a lot of but it can take up more space
than the core application data over time
so it's best to move it out of the
database searching of data should be
allocated to a database that is
specialized in this task such as elastic
search there is still a core
responsibility for transactional systems
for the relational database
especially when complex queries are
needed with traditional relationships
relationships and joints when building
your applications you should look at the
characteristics of your application
requirements to select the right
database if you need referential
integrity integrity with strong
consistency for your transactions then a
relational database is still the best
database for the job if you just need
simple key value based queries that
operate very fast and have a very high
throughput then a no sequel database
like Amazon DynamoDB will be a good fit
documents such as those represented by
JSON are now a common storage
requirement and if you need to index and
process these documents then DynamoDB
supports the document model model too in
an interconnected world you may find
that relationships you try to model look
more like a graph for example in a
social media application there's
relationships between people to help
solve these problems we have a new
database in the preview called Amazon
Neptune for caching requirements we
support Redis and memcache to finally if
you need a search capabilities then
elastic search as I mentioned before is
a great database for the job at AWS we
have a large set of database services
for the workloads that I just went over
but there are many other aspects of data
management and processing that we can
help you address - if we start from the
bottom on this slide you can see that we
have a number of services to help move
data around whether it is for relational
databases with the database migration
service physical storage with snowball
or
streaming data through Kinesis at the
next level
customers are building data lakes on our
object storage services s3 and glacier
glue is a service from ATS that provides
ETL capabilities and a data catalog to
help you find and manage your data in
your data Lake moving up again we have
operational
